trans-unit.source: Provides an editor control that enables end users to edit custom properties on an associated <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> or server control.
This class cannot be inherited.

The PropertyGridEditorPart provides a generic user interface (UI) that enables users to edit custom properties on <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> and server controls placed in <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPartZoneBase> zones.

In contrast, the other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls, such as the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.AppearanceEditorPart> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.BehaviorEditorPart> controls, edit only existing, UI-oriented properties from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> class.

Just as there are tool-oriented zones in the Web Parts control set (for details, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.ToolZone> class overview), there are tool-oriented part controls, and each of these must reside in a corresponding type of tool zone.

These kind of controls in the Web Parts control set have two distinguishing characteristics: - They are helper controls that enable end users to personalize the controls that form the primary UI of a page in a Web Parts application.
- They are visible only in certain page display modes.

The PropertyGridEditorPart control is a special control, and it becomes visible only when a Web page is in edit mode, and when a specific <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> or server control has been selected by a user for editing.

The PropertyGridEditorPart control, like all other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls, must reside in an <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> zone on the page.

> [!IMPORTANT] > An <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZone> zone can contain only <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls, and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls cannot be placed in any other type of zone.

The PropertyGridEditorPart control provides an editing UI for properties that are marked in the source code with the `WebBrowsable` attribute (from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebBrowsableAttribute> class).

When a property is marked with this attribute, a PropertyGridEditorPart control creates the editing UI based on the type of the property, and uses a <xref:System.ComponentModel.PropertyDescriptor> object if needed to convert the value in each editing control to the type of the property.
You can also add other attributes that help the PropertyGridEditorPart control to display the editing UI.

The `WebDisplayName` attribute (from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebDisplayNameAttribute> class) allows you to specify the text for the label that appears with each control in the editing UI.

The `WebDescription` attribute (from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebDescriptionAttribute> class) allows you to specify a string that appears as a ToolTip for each control in the editing UI.
The controls created to edit properties of various types are listed in the following table.

|Property type|Control created to edit the property| |-------------------|------------------------------------------| |String|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox>| |Int, Float, Unit|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox>| |Boolean|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.CheckBox>| |<xref:System.Enum>|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.DropDownList> (contains the list of enumerated values)| |<xref:System.DateTime>|<xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.TextBox>| The PropertyGridEditorPart class has a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart.Title%2A> property, which is used to get or set the visible title text for the control.
There is also a protected <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart.Display%2A> property, which determines whether the control is displayed when the page enters edit mode.

The PropertyGridEditorPart class also has two important methods, <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.BehaviorEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> and <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.BehaviorEditorPart.SyncChanges%2A>, which it inherits from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class and overrides.

The methods are critical because they enable getting and setting the property values between the field values of the editor control and the properties on the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control being edited.

Because the PropertyGridEditorPart control allows you to edit only custom properties, you will need the other <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls in the Web Parts control set to edit the appearance, layout, and behavior of <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls.

The other controls include the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.BehaviorEditorPart>, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.LayoutEditorPart>, and the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.AppearanceEditorPart> controls.

These <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> controls should provide most editing features required to edit <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> controls, but if necessary, you can also create a custom editor control by inheriting from the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class.
For a code example, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> class overview topic.
> [!NOTE] > To improve accessibility, the PropertyGridEditorPart control is rendered within a `<fieldset>` element.

The `<fieldset>` element groups the related set of controls used for editing in the PropertyGridEditorPart control, and it facilitates tabbed navigation among those controls for both visual user agents (such as ordinary Web browsers) and speech-oriented user agents (such as screen-reading software).
Accessibility The markup rendered by default for this control might not conform to accessibility standards such as the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines 1.0 (WCAG) priority 1 guidelines.
For details about accessibility support for this control, see [ASP.NET Controls and Accessibility](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Creates a new instance of the class.

The PropertyGridEditorPart constructor is a default; no constructor is declared in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> class and hence no special tasks are carried out when a new instance of the class is created.

Saves the values from a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart"></xref> control to the corresponding properties in the associated <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control.
The ApplyChanges method is a critical method on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control.

The method saves the values a user has set on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control to the corresponding properties in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control.

The associated control is referenced in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control's inherited <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.WebPartToEdit%2A> property.
> [!IMPORTANT] > You cannot override the ApplyChanges method because the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> type is sealed to prevent inheriting from it.

However, if you need more programmatic control over the process of editing various <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control properties than the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control provides, you can create a custom <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart> control and provide your own implementation of this method.
For a code example, see the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method.

The ApplyChanges method attempts to set the values on public custom properties in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control, provided that those properties each have a `[WebBrowsable(true)]` attribute.
The ApplyChanges method is called when the user clicks a button representing an OK or an apply verb in the editing user interface (UI).
You can also call it directly from your own code if there is a need to save the edited values apart from user actions.

<xref uid="langword_csharp_true" name="true" href=""></xref> if the action of saving values from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart"></xref> to the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> is successful; otherwise (if an error occurs), <xref uid="langword_csharp_false" name="false" href=""></xref>.
An error occurred when trying to set the value for a property on the associated <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref>.
Overrides the base property inherited from the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Panel"></xref> control to hide the property from designers and prevent it from being affected by themes.
Though it is public, this property is used for default rendering of this control and is not intended to be called from developer code.
This property cannot be set by themes or style sheet themes.
For more information, see <xref:System.Web.UI.ThemeableAttribute> and [ASP.NET Themes and Skins](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
A string that contains the ID of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Button"></xref> control that receives the default focus in a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.Panel"></xref> control.
Gets a value that indicates whether a control should be displayed when its associated <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control is in edit mode.
The Display property returns `false` if the value on the base property is also `false`.
Otherwise, if the control to be edited is not `null`, then the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control is displayed.
The Display property applies only when a page is in edit mode, and a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control has been selected for editing.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the control should be displayed.
To be added.
To be added.

Retrieves the values from a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart"></xref> control, and updates the corresponding controls used to edit those property values within a <xref href="System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart"></xref> control.
The SyncChanges method is a critical method on a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control.

It implements the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorPart.SyncChanges%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method from the base class, retrieves the current values from the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control, and updates the controls in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control with those values so a user can edit them.
The SyncChanges method is called whenever the values in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control might have changed.

For a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control, the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.EditorZoneBase> zone that contains the control calls the SyncChanges method immediately after calling the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart.ApplyChanges%2A> method, so that the values in the <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control are always synchronized with the values in the associated <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control.
Another case where the SyncChanges method is called is when a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.WebPart> control is entering edit mode.
Gets or sets a title for the editor control.
The Title property value is displayed in the title bar of a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control when the control is visible in edit mode.
When the control is declared in a page, you can set a value for the `Title` attribute.
If you do not supply a value for the title, a culture-specific default value is supplied.

The Title property overrides the base property so that, if no title value is supplied, a default title appropriate to a <xref:System.Web.UI.WebControls.WebParts.PropertyGridEditorPart> control can be supplied by the Web Parts control set.
A string that is used as the title of the control.
The default value is a calculated control name supplied by the Web Parts control set.
